docs.lead_paragraph: Doni Wilson, a 38-year-old Jakarta taxi driver, has voted only once in his life and swore he'd never do it again after feeling a huge letdown by Indonesia's current president.

headline.main: Indonesia Election Fever Spurs People to Vote
headline.print_headline: Indonesia Election Fever Spurs People to Vote

docs.lead_paragraph: Years after the recession, there are now signs that the labor market is tightening enough that more workers may get raises that significantly exceed inflation.

headline.main: Sign of Spring on Pay: Real Wage Growth
headline.print_headline: Sign of Spring on Pay: Real Wage Growth

docs.abstract: Signs are emerging, years after recession, that labor market is tightening enough to allow for more workers to receive raises that significantly exceed inflation.
docs.snippet: Years after the recession, there are now signs that the labor market is tightening enough that more workers may get raises that significantly exceed inflation.

docs.lead_paragraph: As a proportion of the overall economy, corporate profits were at their highest since 1929, while wages and benefits were at their lowest for any year ever measured.

headline.main: Corporate Profits Grow and Wages Slide
headline.print_headline: Corporate Profits Grow and Wages Slide

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris Off the Charts column; corporate profits, as proportion of overall economy, are at their highest since 1929, while wages and benefits are at their lowest for any year ever measured; Commerce Department estimates that corporations earned $2.1 trillion during 2013, paying $419 billion in taxes, with after-tax profit of $1.7 trillion, or 10 percent of gross domestic product during year.
docs.snippet: As a proportion of the overall economy, corporate profits were at their highest since 1929, while wages and benefits were at their lowest for any year ever measured.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration said the increases were much greater in states that expanded Medicaid eligibility under the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Law Lifts Enrollment in Medicaid by Millions
headline.print_headline: Law Lifts Enrollment in Medicaid by Millions

docs.abstract: Obama administration reports that enrollment in Medicaid has increased by three million people, to a total of 62 million, largely because of the Affordable Care Act; as expected, increases were much greater in states that expanded Medicaid eligibility.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration said the increases were much greater in states that expanded Medicaid eligibility under the Affordable Care Act.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three million lower-income Americans have enrolled in the Medicaid program for the poor so far during the rollout of U.S. President Barack Obama's healthcare reform law, the administration announced on Friday.

headline.main: U.S. Reports Three Million Medicaid Enrollments Under Obamacare
headline.print_headline: U.S. Reports Three Million Medicaid Enrollments Under Obamacare

docs.snippet: Three million lower-income Americans have enrolled in the Medicaid program for the poor so far during the rollout of U.S. President Barack Obama's healthcare reform law, the administration announced on Friday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans thinking about buying health insurance on their own later this year, or maybe switching to a different insurer, are probably out of luck. The policies are going off the market as a little-noticed consequence of President Barack Obama's health care overhaul.

headline.main: Even the Healthy Locked Out of 2014 Policies Now
headline.print_headline: Even the Healthy Locked Out of 2014 Policies Now

docs.lead_paragraph: Why those seven million enrollments in Obamacare matter.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column contends news that more than seven million Americans have signed up for insurance on health insurance exchanges established by the health care reform law is a significant political victory for Democrats; concedes that while supporters of the law are right to remain cautious, urges them to celebrate law's success.
docs.snippet: Why those seven million enrollments in Obamacare matter.

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials in five states said that their health insurance exchanges had been hobbled by problems like those that bedeviled the federal marketplace.

headline.main: State Officials Cite Technology Problems on Health Insurance Sites
headline.print_headline: Health Exchange Officials Cite Technology Problems

docs.abstract: Officials in five states, on the defensive at congressional hearing, say that their health insurance exchanges have been hobbled by technology problems like those that bedeviled the federal marketplace; say their states, Hawaii, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota and Oregon, are recovering.
docs.snippet: Officials in five states said that their health insurance exchanges had been hobbled by problems like those that bedeviled the federal marketplace.
